title: Broken Heart Syndrome (Stress Cardiomyopathy)
author: Mary Jo DiLonardo

sections.heading: What Is Broken Heart Syndrome?
content: Broken heart syndrome is a condition with symptoms that may feel like a heart attack, such as chest pain and shortness of breath . It can happen after you go through a very stressful physical or emotional event, such as a stroke or the death of someone you love. Your doctor may call this stress-induced cardiomyopathy.
Broken heart syndrome symptoms are similar to those of a heart attack. If have pain in your chest, you should seek immediate medical attention. (Photo credit: LaylaBird)
How did the broken heart syndrome get its name?

Much of the early research into this condition came from Japan, where it was called takotsubo cardiomyopathy or takotsubo syndrome. That's because it causes one of the heart's chambers to take on an unusual shape that resembles that of a traditional pot used in Japan to catch octopus, called a takotsubo. Researchers also called it transient left ventricular apical ballooning.

A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine in 2005 noted that many of the people being treated for the condition had recently experienced the death of a loved one. The name broken heart syndrome took off in popular culture.

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome Causes
content: During a stressful event, your body releases stress hormones such as adrenaline. High amounts of adrenaline can cause the arteries that bring blood to your heart to get smaller. This lowers blood flow to your heart. Adrenaline can also bind to heart cells, causing excess calcium to enter, which makes it harder for your heart to beat normally.

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome Triggers
content: Broken heart syndrome can be triggered by stressful emotional events, whether good or bad, such as:
bullets: Grief from the death of a loved one or pet
Loss of a relationship, job, or money
Surprises, such as surprise parties or winning the lottery

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome Risk Factors
content: You have a higher risk of broken heart syndrome if you:
bullets: Are a woman or assigned female at birth
Have had seizures or a stroke
Have had a mental health problem such as anxiety or depression

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome Diagnosis
content: There are several tests your doctor might do to find out if you have broken heart syndrome. They use many of these to rule out a heart attack.
Physical exam and history. Your doctor will examine you and ask about your symptoms. They'll want to know about any major events or stress you've had lately.

sections.heading: Electrocardiogram (EKG).
content: Your doctor will do one of these to look for any problems with your heart's rhythm and structure. The results will let them know if your symptoms are from a heart attack.
Blood tests. It's common to have higher blood levels of cardiac enzymes when you have broken heart syndrome.
Coronary angiogram. This test looks for blockages in your heart. People with heart attacks usually have them, while those with broken heart symptoms typically don't.
Echocardiogram. This test shows your doctor if you have an enlarged heart or if your heart has an abnormal shape while it pumps, which can indicate broken heart syndrome .
Cardiac MRI. This test gives your doctor detailed images of your heart structure and function to further help them diagnose your condition.
Broken heart syndrome vs. heart attack

They may feel the same, but they’re different. Heart attacks are caused by blockages of waxy buildup within the arteries leading to your heart. With broken heart syndrome, there aren’t any blockages; the heart just doesn’t pump blood as well as it should, which causes heart attack-like symptoms .

bullets: Fluid backing up into your lungs (pulmonary edema)

Taking care of your overall health is another way to help you manage physical and emotional stress:

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome Outlook
content: Most people recover in a few weeks. Some people feel fatigued for a while afterward, which could make you feel depressed. You should talk to your doctor if this happens.
Can you die from broken heart syndrome?
It's very rare, but death is possible in up to 8% of cases. Most people make a full recovery.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Broken heart syndrome is a condition in which your heart doesn't pump normally. It comes on suddenly, often after an emotionally stressful event. It usually isn't fatal, but it's hard to tell the difference between broken heart syndrome and a heart attack. If you feel symptoms such as chest pain and trouble breathing, call 911.

sections.heading: Broken Heart Syndrome FAQs
content: What does broken heart syndrome feel like?
Broken heart syndrome feels like a heart attack. You may have chest pain, trouble breathing, and an irregular heartbeat. You may also feel faint, dizzy, or sweaty.
Can broken heart syndrome be cured?
Yes. You may get medicines to lessen the strain on your heart by lowering your blood pressure. You may also get medicines to lower your risk of developing a blood clot.

sections.heading: How long can broken heart syndrome last?
content: Most people recover quickly from broken heart syndrome. You may start to feel better within a few hours of starting treatment. It doesn't usually cause lasting damage, and you'll likely be back to normal within a month. But some people continue to feel weak and tired for several months.
What does a broken heart syndrome X-ray look like?

Imaging tests often show a distinctive shape of the left ventricle — the heart's main pumping chamber. Its pumping ability is weakened, causing it to bulge or balloon. The shape is similar to that of a jar with a wider base and narrower neck.
